page.title: 06FOLK LORE
page.content: THE CHEESE WELL. ONE HOT SUNNY DAY IN JUNE, SIX OF US IN TRAQUAIR SCHOOL P3 WALKED UP TO THE CHEESE WELL. WE SET OFF UP A TRACK WHICH HAS BEEN A ROAD FOR SEVEN HUNDRED YEARS. THE TRACK IS VERY ROUGH, BORDERED BY WILD FRUIT AND FLOWERS. IT CLIMBS STEEPLY THROUGH FIELDS THEN WOODS OF LARCH, SPRUCE AND PINE, THEN OVER OPEN HEATHER AND BLAEBERRY COVERED HILLSIDE AT THE TOP, TO JOIN THE VALLEYS OF THE TWEED AND YARROW, THE ANCIENT ROUTE FROM TRAQUAIR TO SELKIRK. IN THE OLD DAYS BEARS, WOLVES AND ROBBERS WOULD HAVE ROAMED THE FORESTS AND HILLSIDES. AT THE PIPERS KNOLL WE LISTENED FOR THE SOUND OF THE LONE PIPERS. WE CLIMDED TO THE TOP OF THE HILL AND SAW THE BRIGHT YELLOW OF THE WILD DAFFODILS, GROWING BY THE CHEESE WELL. TWO STONES MARK THE WELL ON THE RIGHT OF THE PATH
